meta.content: Previous studies have documented the occurrence of veterinary sulfonamide antibiotics in groundwater and rivers located far from pollution sources, although their transport and fate is relatively unknown. In mountainous agricultural fields, the transport behaviour can be influenced by climate, slope and physico-chemical properties of the sulfonamides. The objective of this research is to describe the transport behaviour of three sulfonamide antibiotics (sulfamethoxazole, sulfadimethoxine and sulfamethazine) in sloped agricultural fields located in the Haean catchment, South Korea. During dry and monsoon seasons, a solute transport experiment was conducted in two typical sandy loam agricultural fields after application of antibiotics and potassium bromide as conservative tracers. Field measurement and modelling revealed that frequency and amount of runoff generation indicate a relation between slope and rain intensity during monsoon season. Since the steepness of slope influenced partitioning of precipitation between runoff and subsurface flow, higher loss of sulfonamide antibiotics and bromide by runoff was observed at the steeper sloped field. Bromide on topsoil rapidly infiltrated at high infiltration rates. On the contrary, the sulfonamides were relatively retarded in the upper soil layer due to adsorption onto soil particles. Presence of furrows and ridges affected the distribution of sulfonamide antibiotics in the subsurface due to gradient from wetter furrows to drier ridges induced by topography. Modelling results with HydroGeoSphere matched with background studies that describe physico-chemical properties of the sulfonamides interaction between soil and the antibiotic group, solute transport through vadose zone and runoff generation by storm events.

meta.content: Transport of sulfonamide antibiotics in crop fields during monsoon season - Environmental Science and Pollution Research

Previous studies have documented the occurrence of veterinary sulfonamide antibiotics in groundwater and rivers located far from pollution sources, although their transport and fate is relatively unknown. In mountainous agricultural fields, the transport behaviour can be influenced by climate, slope and physico-chemical properties of the sulfonamides. The objective of this research is to describe the transport behaviour of three sulfonamide antibiotics (sulfamethoxazole, sulfadimethoxine and sulfamethazine) in sloped agricultural fields located in the Haean catchment, South Korea. During dry and monsoon seasons, a solute transport experiment was conducted in two typical sandy loam agricultural fields after application of antibiotics and potassium bromide as conservative tracers. Field measurement and modelling revealed that frequency and amount of runoff generation indicate a relation between slope and rain intensity during monsoon season. Since the steepness of slope influenced partitioning of precipitation between runoff and subsurface flow, higher loss of sulfonamide antibiotics and bromide by runoff was observed at the steeper sloped field. Bromide on topsoil rapidly infiltrated at high infiltration rates. On the contrary, the sulfonamides were relatively retarded in the upper soil layer due to adsorption onto soil particles. Presence of furrows and ridges affected the distribution of sulfonamide antibiotics in the subsurface due to gradient from wetter furrows to drier ridges induced by topography. Modelling results with HydroGeoSphere matched with background studies that describe physico-chemical properties of the sulfonamides interaction between soil and the antibiotic group, solute transport through vadose zone and runoff generation by storm events.

div.p: Previous studies have documented the occurrence of veterinary sulfonamide antibiotics in groundwater and rivers located far from pollution sources, although their transport and fate is relatively unknown. In mountainous agricultural fields, the transport behaviour can be influenced by climate, slope and physico-chemical properties of the sulfonamides. The objective of this research is to describe the transport behaviour of three sulfonamide antibiotics (sulfamethoxazole, sulfadimethoxine and sulfamethazine) in sloped agricultural fields located in the Haean catchment, South Korea. During dry and monsoon seasons, a solute transport experiment was conducted in two typical sandy loam agricultural fields after application of antibiotics and potassium bromide as conservative tracers. Field measurement and modelling revealed that frequency and amount of runoff generation indicate a relation between slope and rain intensity during monsoon season. Since the steepness of slope influenced partitioning of precipitation between runoff and subsurface flow, higher loss of sulfonamide antibiotics and bromide by runoff was observed at the steeper sloped field. Bromide on topsoil rapidly infiltrated at high infiltration rates. On the contrary, the sulfonamides were relatively retarded in the upper soil layer due to adsorption onto soil particles. Presence of furrows and ridges affected the distribution of sulfonamide antibiotics in the subsurface due to gradient from wetter furrows to drier ridges induced by topography. Modelling results with HydroGeoSphere matched with background studies that describe physico-chemical properties of the sulfonamides interaction between soil and the antibiotic group, solute transport through vadose zone and runoff generation by storm events.

Soil column experiments have been widely used to describe transport of sulfonamides in soils (Wehrhan et al.
2007
; Unold et al.
2009
; Kwon
2011
). The degree of transport in soil column is affected by sorption, degradation and solubility of sulfonamide antibiotics (Boxall
2008
). The transport was described with models including multiple sorption sites and flow channels to account for the heterogeneity of soil (Brusseau and Rao
1989
; Engelhardt et al.
2015
). Wehrhan et al. (
2007
) showed that kinetic models based on the Freundlich sorption isotherm can describe transport of sulfonamide antibiotics in soil column.

During summer monsoon, intensive precipitations are frequent in Korea, making organic pollutants remaining in agricultural soils prone to be transported into rivers and lakes (Yu et al.
2001
; Kim et al.
2007
). The transport behaviour was influenced by intensity and amount of rainfall (Kim et al.
2007
). In mountainous agricultural regions, slope can play an important role in partitioning of rain water into runoff and subsurface flow associated with pollutant transport (Pitlick
1994
; Dodds
1997
; Harden and Scruggs
2003
). The South Korean territory consists of about 70 % mountainous area, and agriculture on slopes is common. Due to the potential toxicity for aquatic organisms, concentrations and amounts of veterinary sulfonamide antibiotics, frequently found in croplands should be addressed in combination with field study and modelling.

The objective of this study was to depict transport and fate of selected sulfonamide antibiotics (sulfamethoxazole (SMX), sulfadimethoxine (SDM) and sulfamethazine (SMZ)) in two sloped agricultural fields during monsoon season, in combination with field measurements and a numerical modelling using HydroGeoSphere. We hypothesised that the removal of sulfonamides by runoff is higher in steeper parts of the sloped field. In contrast, we hypothesised that their mobility in subsurface region is enhanced in the flatter sloped field during monsoon season. We also examined the effect of their sorption capacity on partitioning solutes into subsurface water flow and surface runoff.

The steep farmlands surrounded by mountainous ridges are mainly covered with acidic and podzolic Cambisols formed from weathered granite (Meusburger et al.
2013
; Ruidisch et al.
2013
). Due to high soil erosion caused by runoff generation during summer monsoon season, sandy soil is frequently added in order to compensate soil loss. Therefore, the agricultural land management is strongly relevant to the fast pollutant leaching from top soil to adjacent soil horizons.

During our field experiments (from 20 May to 10 July 2011), characteristic summer monsoon precipitation events were observed (Fig.
2
). The field experiments were performed at two different potato fields (rectangle plot: L, 8.0 m; W, 2.1 m) located on mountainous slopes within Haean catchment (N 38° 16′, E 128° 8′; altitude, 620 m). The fields were managed with a ridge-furrow system, and the slope of each field was 9.0° for field A and 4.5° for field B (Fig.
1
). Soil properties of the experiment fields are shown in Table
1
. Two hundred milligrammes of sulfamethoxazole, sulfadimethoxine and sulfamethazine (Sigma-Aldrich, Seelze, Germany) and 10 kg KBr (Merck, Darmstadt, Germany) were applied to the upper 2 cm in the top soil on 20 May 2011 in each field. Before applying the sulfonamides and bromide, seed potatoes planted on 15 May were eliminated to prevent absorption of the antibiotics and bromide tracer by potato growth.

div.p:
The experimental design for runoff and subsurface flow measurement is shown in Fig.
2
. Tensiometers and FDR sensors (Decagon 10HS moisture sensors, Decagon Devices Inc., Pullman, USA) were installed in two fields with different slopes (field A, 9.0°; field B, 4.5°). In two furrows and three ridges of each field, the tensiometers were set up in depths of 20, 40 and 70 cm from the surface of the furrows and ridges (Fig.
1
). The difference of height between furrows and ridges was 15 cm. The data from FDR sensors (Decagon 10HS moisture sensors, Decagon Devices Inc., Pullman, USA) and pressure sensors were automatically collected using Em50 Digital/Analogue Data Logger (Decagon Devices Inc., Pullman, USA) and Delta-T logger (Delta-T Devices Ltd., Cambridge, United Kingdom). In each ridge and each furrow, tensiometers and suction candles designed to collect soil water were also installed in depths of 20, 40 and 70 cm from surface (Fig.
1
). The distance between tensiometers and suction candles in ridges and furrows was 2 m.

The target sulfonamides in water samples were analysed using high-performance liquid chromatography with mass spectrometry (Waters, Quattro micro TM API, Milford, MA). Sulfamethoxazole-D

Twenty millilitres of water sample was filtered through a 0.22-μm PES membrane (Millipore, Billerica, MA) to separate suspended particles in the sample. The used filters were sonicated in 5 ml methanol (Th. Geyer GmbH, Renningen, Germany) for 30 min in order to extract adsorbed antibiotics onto suspended particles, and then the extract was dissolved in 200 mL deionised water to reduce the solvent effect. Through solid phase extraction (SPE) using OASIS HLB cartridge (Waters, Milford, MA), target antibiotics were more concentrated in 1 mL extraction (acetonitrile: water, 3:7). After the runoff and pore water was filtered with 0.22 μm PES membrane, bromide concentration in the aliquot was measured with ion-selective electrode (Metrohm, Zofingen, Switzerland) for bromide in combination with reference electrode (EPA
1996
).

To investigate water and solute transport under monsoonal conditions, both surface and subsurface processes need to be considered. These processes were quantitatively depicted using HydroGeoSphere, a fully integrated 3D surface/subsurface model considering precipitation and evapotranspiration. To consider topographic variations for overland flow, concept of rill storage is implemented in HydroGeoSphere. The overland flow parameters for rill storage, rill storage height and coupling length were set to 1 cm, as given in previous study performed in same region (Ruidisch et al.
2013
). The model domain was divided into three subsurface zones (0–30, 30–60 and 60–100 cm), and different soil physical properties as given in Table

were attributed to these zones.

The initial pressure head conditions in the subsurface domain were set to observed pressure head measured by field tensiometers. The simulation of water and solute transport started according to the application day of sulfonamide antibiotics and bromide on top soil (23 May). Since the sulfonamide antibiotics were applied only in the upper part of the top soil layer, the initial concentrations of each sulfonamide (0.62 mg/kg) and bromide (31.0 g/kg) were defined within the upper 2 cm depth from surface, corresponding to the application rates in the experimental plots. Initial concentrations for the subsurface domain (3–100 cm) were set to zero. The bottom boundary condition of the model was defined as free drainage in 1 m depth. The lateral boundary was set to zero-flux boundary due to block panels inserted around subsurface region.

Several mechanisms of runoff generation (e.g. infiltration-excess surface runoff, saturation-excess runoff) have been suggested (Horton
1933
; Hewlett and Hibbert
1967
; Freeze
1974
). To measure water contents, we installed FDR probes in depths of 20, 40 and 70 cm. When soil was very dry, runoff was not generated, and all rainfall quickly infiltrated with higher infiltration rates as previously depicted under similar dry conditions (Yair
1983
;
1996
; Lavee et al. 1998). When the soil was wet, runoff was easily generated. Although the top soil layer (<20 cm) was not saturated after a 7.2-mm/h precipitation event on 8 June, runoff generation was observed. In both cases, it could be termed infiltration-excess surface runoff. After heavy rainfalls over 17.0 mm/h, the water saturation occurred, and then the runoff occurred due to saturation excess of subsurface region. Therefore, both infiltration-excess runoff and saturation-excess runoff were generated during the rainy season.

As shown in Fig.
3
and from calculated Nash-Sutcliffe efficiencies (field A, 0.83; field B, 0.79), the comparison between simulated and observed surface runoff had a good agreement for both fields. The runoff generation in dry season was simulated reasonably well, but the model underestimated runoff generation in monsoon season. Due to heterogeneity of field conditions and simplifications of governing equations used in this model, underestimations of the runoff generation have been reported under extreme rain events such as summer monsoon rainfall (Moore and Owens
1984
; Wu et al.
1993
). HydroGeoSphere does not a priori assume precipitation-runoff generation mechanisms, and uses simplifications of governing equations, such as two-dimensional Saint Venant equations (Brunner and Simmons
2012
). Furthermore, underestimation of the runoff generation has been reported under extreme rainfalls, due to heterogeneity of the field sites and fluctuation of rainfall intensity (Gupta and Panigrahy
2008
; Li et al.
2014
).

div.h3: Bromide and sulfonamide antibiotics in runoff
div.p:
As shown in Fig.
4
, high concentration of the sulfonamide antibiotics was observed in runoff generated by precipitation on 31 May. Concentration of the antibiotics decreased during the strong precipitation like bromide. Compared with bromide, decrement of the antibiotics concentration was relatively low. The difference may be induced by higher sorption rates of sulfonamide antibiotics to soil particles, especially in the top soil layer within 2 cm where runoff generation and solute exchange occurred. In batch sorption experiment for adsorption coefficient (
K
d
), the estimated value of chosen antibiotics was at least 500-fold higher than bromide. In contrast, behaviour among the sulfonamide antibiotics in runoff was not different.
Concentration of Br, sulfamethoxazole, sulfadimethoxine and sulfamethazine in runoff from fields A and B

Electrostatic interactions can be easily induced between soil particles and positive forms of the antibiotics, since surface of soil suspended particles are generally negatively charged (Avisar et al.
2010
). In this study, the pH of runoff was 5.2–5.9. Decreasing pH values led to increased sorption potential of the antibiotics on soil material in pH range of 4.0–8.0. This resulted from abundance of neutral and positive-charged sulfonamides species at the pH range, which electrostatically bind to sorption sites on soil surface (Park and Huwe
2016
). The electrostatic interaction between the sulfonamide antibiotics and organic matter can facilitate transport in soil water interface, and consequently enhance mobility of the antibiotics by soil materials (Tolls
2001
; Kulshrestha et al.
2004
; Magee et al.
1991
).

As given in Table
2
and Fig.
4
, simulation of the antibiotics transport with HydroGeoSphere had a good agreement with measured values. Nevertheless, the transport model underestimated washout of the applied sulfonamides by runoff, especially during summer monsoon season. HydroGeoSphere code can simulate fully integrated surface and subsurface water flow and solute transport. However, the model does not consider soil erosion and particle-facilitated transport, which is an important transport mechanism during heavy rain events triggering loss of soil particles and organic matters.

div.p: The concentrations of antibiotics in runoff were not different among the applied sulfonamide in the whole experiment, except during the first runoff event (31 May). The precipitation on 31 May led to fast movement of applied sulfonamides into the subsurface region. In accordance with the modelling and analytic result, the distribution among sulfonamide antibiotics was similar within the upper soil layer (<10 cm), where solute exchange between runoff and subsurface flow occurred. This finding also suggests that nonequilibrium sorption was dominant on top soil layer in the whole period.

In the present study, slopes of the fields significantly affected the transport of sulfonamide antibiotics and bromide by runoff. From Fig.
4
, it appears that the sulfonamide concentrations in runoff from field A were higher compared with field B during the whole period. During the rainy season starting on 23 June, bromide concentrations from field A were also relatively higher compared with field B. The difference of runoff generation was responsible for the large difference in concentrations of the sulfonamide antibiotics and bromide.
div.h3: Transport of bromide and sulfonamide antibiotics in soils
div.p:
In this study, bromide has been applied on top soil (0–1 cm) as conservative tracer to describe water flow in the experiment field. To confirm background level of Br, 1 m soil column was taken and concentration of bromide was estimated. No bromide was detected in whole top and subsurface layers before bromide application. As shown in Figs.
5
and
6
, detection of the bromide tracer in soil water exhibited a considerable spatial variability, after precipitations were observed. From surface, the concentration front of the conservative tracer moved toward into deeper soil layers on 30 May. The other two rain events, which occurred before the monsoon season, also transported the bromide from the top layer into deeper soil layer, but the distribution changed only a little, due to low precipitation rates. During the heavy rainy season, distribution of the bromide changed in the subsurface region, and rapidly moved into deeper soil layer. The transport pattern of bromide indicates that water flow in subsurface region was very fast during the rainy season. This coincides with high hydraulic conductivity and other Van Genuchten parameters estimated by Parallel PEST.

Compared with the conservative tracer, transport of the sulfonamide antibiotics was relatively retarded in the soil during the whole experiment period. Most amount of the applied antibiotics was restricted to the upper soil layer (≤10 cm) and was not detected in depths of 40 and 70 cm until 23 June. During the dry season, concentration of the sulfonamides decreased with increasing depth of the subsurface area. After the rainy season started, the applied antibiotics were rapidly penetrated in subsurface region. The high water infiltration led to fast transport of antibiotics into deeper subsurface region, regardless of runoff generation. Figures
5
and
6
show that transport of sulfadimethoxine was relatively retarded in upper soil layer compared with other target sulfonamides. The estimated
K
d
values of the antibiotics is as follows; sulfadimethoxine (field A, 1.86 L/kg; field B, 1.84 L/kg) > sulfamethoxazole (field A, 1.45 L/kg; field B, 1.47 L/kg) > sulfamethazine (field A, 1.26 L/kg; field B, 1.15 L/kg). The results from modelling and chemical analysis indicate that distribution and transport of the sulfonamide antibiotics in subsurface is dependent on their sorption capacity (
K
d
). Several studies showed that
K
d
values of the target antibiotics for different soils varying between 0.23 and 6.90 L/kg (Thurman and Lindsey
2000
; Langhammer
1989
; Lertpaitoonpan et al.
2009
; Srinivasan et al.
2010
; Wegst-Uhrich et al.
2014
). This was coincided with our measured
K
d
values (sulfadimethoxine, 3.87–4.13 L/kg; sulfamethoxazole, 2.98–3.14 L/kg; sulfamethazine, 2.57–2.74 L/kg). The estimated
K
d
values by HydroGeoSphere was 2–4-fold lower than measured values. The results strongly imply that nonequilibrium sorption was prominent during the entire experimental period. During heavy rainfalls, the nonequilibrium process was also identified as to play an important role in transport of organic pollutants (Baskaran et al.
1996
; Arias-Estévez et al.
2008
; Streek et al.
1995
).

The ridge-furrow system used in this study affected water movement in the soil layer (Figs.
5
and
6
). This caused difference of pressure heads between ridges and furrows. At field A, pressure heads between ridge and furrow differed from −20 to −120 cm, while difference in pressure heads were from −10 to −160 cm at field B. Although pressure head gradient was more pronounced vertically at both fields (field A, −7 to −316 cm; field B, −3 to −319 cm), the horizontal gradient partially induced soil water movement from furrows to ridges. During monsoon season, difference between vertical and horizontal pressure head gradient was significantly reduced due to strong precipitation. This led to transport of the applied sulfonamide antibiotics from furrow to ridge. Therefore, differences in the distribution of sulfonamide antibiotics were induced by the ridge-furrow system.

As shown in Figs.
5
and
6
, the slope of the fields also affected the distribution of sulfonamide antibiotics in the subsurface region. The distribution of sulfonamide antibiotics in subsurface was not different between the fields before monsoon season, and all sulfonamide antibiotics were only detectable in the top soil layer above 20 cm depth. The difference in the residual concentration of all sulfonamides between the fields became apparent below 70 cm depth during monsoon season. In 70 cm depth of field A, residual concentration of sulfadimethoxine increased up to 1.90 μg/L. Under the rainy period, a higher concentration of sulfadimethoxine (0–0.32 μg/L) was detected in the same depth of field B, due to relatively higher water infiltration rate.

For the solute transport, the simulation with HydroGeoSphere showed a good agreement with the measured values. Nevertheless, the calibrated model underestimated transport of the sulfonamide antibiotics and the conservative tracer. In general, tillage changes soil structure in top soil layer, which would be important for generation of preferential flow (Petersen et al.
1999
; Elliott et al.
2000
). There was also considerable earthworm activity which is expected to make tunnels for preferential flow. Several studies have reported that rapid transport of solute is associated with preferential flow (Larsson et al.
1999
; Zheng and Gorelick
2003
). Consequently, the chemical composition of preferential flow might affect the concentration of soil water and overland flow near surface.

In this study, we combined a field study with numerical modelling using the HydroGeoSphere code to investigate transport behaviour of sulfonamide antibiotics and bromide during dry and monsoon season. Steep slopes supported runoff generation, while subsurface flow dominated in less steep slopes. This led to higher loss of the sulfonamide antibiotics and bromide by runoff during the rainy season. The model has a good agreement with measured concentrations of the sulfonamide antibiotics in the runoff, whereas runoff of sulfonamide antibiotics induced by the first rain event was underestimated. In the simulation, the underestimation of the sulfonamides loss by runoff suggested that particle-facilitated transport might be a key transport mechanism in agricultural fields. To improve the understanding of transport processes including the transport of antibiotics attached to soil particles, further research combining experiments and modelling are required.

At both field sites, the sulfonamide antibiotics moved rapidly into subsurface region during monsoon season. Before the rainy period, most amount of the sulfonamide antibiotics remained within topsoil layer (<20 cm depth), while bromide penetrated fast into subsurface. Lower infiltration rates caused by a steeper slope led to a fast transport of all applied sulfonamide antibiotics and bromide in field B into deeper soils layers compared with field A. Our simulation properly described distribution of the sulfonamides and bromide in the subsurface region, although their transport was underestimated during the monsoon season, implying the existence of preferential flow. The understanding and characteristics of sulfonamide transport needs to be incorporated into other hydrological models to depict their toxicological issues in catchments and at watershed level.

Findings of our study can be implemented to set management practises for the refractory pharmaceuticals. Our study implies that whereas runoff and soil erosion control practises will be required to achieve reductions in pharmaceutical contamination of surface water, tillage management approaches will be effective in reducing the occurrence of pharmaceuticals in groundwater. Our study opens up the feasibility of modelling approach at field scale.
